title: MPs say they don’t have enough time to read 110-page Brexit deal
text:
Boris Johnson hopes to force his deal through the Commons in three days, but former leadership rival Rory Stewart wants more time to debate it (Picture: Rex/PA)

Boris Johnson urged MPs to back his Brexit deal ahead of a final bid to force it through Parliament in time for the UK’s departure at the end of the month.

However, many are deeply unhappy at being given just three days to digest the Withdrawal Agreement Bill, which runs to 110 pages with a further 124 pages of explanatory notes.

The Prime Minister faces an uphill battle to fast-track the Bill through the Commons in time for it to be considered by the House of Lords over the weekend.

But he remains confident that the government has the numbers to secure its passage, despite their defeat in Saturday’s special sitting.

Failure to do so would leave him in the position of having to accept another lengthy delay – something he has vowed not to do.

The Prime Minister hopes the Bill can reach the House of Lords by the weekend (Picture: PA)

Rory Stewart said he had been discussing ways to give Parliament more control of the next phase of Brexit negotiations (Picture: Ken McKay/ITV/Rex)

Former Tory Rory Stewart revealed he and a number of ousted Remainer rebels had been locked in talks ‘through the night’ to give Parliament more control over the next phase of Brexit negotiations.

The former leadership candidate wants ministers to be given the opportunity to vote for a further extension to the talks.

He also suggested MPs should be handed a ‘central role’ in trade negotiations.

The Independent London mayoral candidate said he had been discussing the issue ‘yesterday and through the night’ with a number of colleagues who lost the party whip over their support for the Benn Act.

‘I think there is a bigger prize which is making sure that any parliament that is sitting has proper control over the mandate for the future trading negotiations,’ Mr Stewart told the BBC.

Mr Johnson urged MPs to get behind his deal (Picture: AFP)

‘Parliament should be involved in the mandate, the progress of those and the outcome and determining the extension.

‘That’s the bigger prize. If we can make sure that Parliament has a central role in the future negotiations then that’s our democratic opportunity.’

Mr Stewart said he agreed with the Bill, but suggested it needed more than the three days’ worth of debate allocated by the government.

‘If we are going to deliver Brexit, we need to deliver it in a way that Brexiteers and Remainers believe was taken through Parliament fairly,’ he added.

‘That doesn’t mean extending until the end of the year but it does mean we need a few days to do it properly. If we don’t do it properly, we are going to undermine the thing from the beginning.’

MPs had more time to debate the Wild Animals in Circuses Act (affecting 19 animals) than they will to decide the future of 65 million people 🐪👩‍👩‍👧‍👦🦓 It’s hard to think of anything which better illustrates this Govt’s contempt for people, Parliament & democracy #Brexit — Caroline Lucas (@CarolineLucas) October 22, 2019

Caroline Lucas tweeted that ministers had been given more time to debate the Wild Animals in Circuses Act than the Withdrawal Bill.

The former leader of the Greens added: ‘It’s hard to think of anything which better illustrates this government’s contempt for people, Parliament and democracy.’

Angela Rayner, Labour’s shadow education secretary, also said Parliament must be given enough time to properly scrutinise the Bill.

‘Parliament has to be at the centre of everything that happens because that’s what we were doing, weren’t we? Taking back control,’ she told BBC Radio 4’s Today programme.

‘And therefore the control is not for Boris Johnson to have his own little games, it’s about Parliament being able to scrutinise and have a say on what happens.’

Shadow foreign secretary Emily Thornberry agreed more time was needed ‘for politicians to do their job properly’.

She told BBC Breakfast: ‘The idea that we are going to be bounced, as a country, out of the European Union in a few days, without politicians being given a chance to look carefully at the basis on which we’re making this decision, is wrong.’

Leader of the House Jacob Rees-Mogg said those who do not vote for the programme motion ‘will noy be voting for Brexit’ by Halloween (Picture: UK Parliament/EPA)

However, Leader of the House Jacob Rees-Mogg warned on Monday that the programme motion was essential if they were to meet the Halloween deadline.

‘People who do not vote for the programme motion will not be voting for Brexit on October 31,’ he said.

Advertisement

The first vote on Tuesday will be on the Bill’s ‘in principle’ second reading.

Despite the opposition of the DUP over arrangements for Northern Ireland, ministers believe they have the support of pro-Leave Labour rebels and former Tory MPs now sitting as independents who would rather leave with Mr Johnson’s deal than no deal at all.

If they get through the second reading, the government will hope it gives the momentum to carry through the programme motion as well.

If that passes, under the proposed timetable, the Bill would then move to the committee stage – which will continue on into Wednesday – when MPs will have the opportunity to put down amendments.

These are expected to include attempts to keep the UK more closely aligned with the EU through a customs union and to stage a second referendum.

Both are bitterly opposed by the government, raising the possibility that it could pull the Bill altogether if either gets through.
